subject: Reset device namespace when adding to the namespace fails
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2024-01-05 11:23:06.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/agent/linux/interface.py', 'neutron/tests/unit/agent/linux/test_interface.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/b27ea5fe2da47d134ac9b4a50341a0ecc0934eb3', 'message': 'Reset device namespace when adding to the namespace fails

In case when during adding device to the namespace, device will be "shy"
and will disappear for a moment and NetworkInterfaceNotFound exception
will be raised, we need to reset device.namespace to be None.
Otherwise, in the next attempt of adding interface to namespace, when it
will be added back to ovs (and will be in global scope), Neutron will
already look for it in the "namespace" and that will always be failing.

Closes-bug: #1961740
Change-Id: Ie9331c72c44084b0a382598c3359214cce2f2ebd
(cherry picked from commit 76578393ab401a33084921c4355af8e82c5d02ee)
'}]
commit_message:
Reset device namespace when adding to the namespace fails

In case when during adding device to the namespace, device will be "shy"
and will disappear for a moment and NetworkInterfaceNotFound exception
will be raised, we need to reset device.namespace to be None.
Otherwise, in the next attempt of adding interface to namespace, when it
will be added back to ovs (and will be in global scope), Neutron will
already look for it in the "namespace" and that will always be failing.

Closes-bug: #1961740
Change-Id: Ie9331c72c44084b0a382598c3359214cce2f2ebd

will be raised, we need to reset device.namespace to be None.

commit_message:
Reset device namespace when adding to the namespace fails

In case when during adding device to the namespace, device will be "shy"
and will disappear for a moment and NetworkInterfaceNotFound exception
will be raised, we need to reset device.namespace to be None.
Otherwise, in the next attempt of adding interface to namespace, when it
will be added back to ovs (and will be in global scope), Neutron will
already look for it in the "namespace" and that will always be failing.

Closes-bug: #1961740
Change-Id: Ie9331c72c44084b0a382598c3359214cce2f2ebd
(cherry picked from commit 76578393ab401a33084921c4355af8e82c5d02ee)

commit_message:
Increase port name size and type to internal

This patch increases the port name size in
"test_port_creation_and_deletion" and adds explicit exceptions
with debugging information.

The port is now type=internal.

This patch also reverts [1] that marked the test as unstable.

[1]https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/873941

Closes-Bug: #2006603
Change-Id: If85b487dc2db7466c4848043911772ef79140d51
(cherry picked from commit 4b8e484e1ded99012a8e332fa1c9ac660f74a17e)

commit_message:
[stable-only] Remove all TripleO CI jobs

This patch is removing all the TripleO CI jobs.

The "neutron-ovn-tripleo-ci-centos-9-containers-multinode" job is
currently failing in the TripleO installation phase since 2023-12-20.

Change-Id: I626609f00fb417216e147c0067da77d6703e7d4f

commit_message:
[OVN] "description" property missing in ``NeutronAgent``

The "description" property abstract method definition is missing in
the abstract class ``NeutronAgent``. This property is being used in
this definition, in the "as_dict" method.

Trivial-Fix

Change-Id: I18029707414fc361b36e85326e2e9dadd7d6c336

commit_message:
[FT] Remove test "test_get_datapath_id"

The method to retrieve an OVS bridge datapath ID have proven to work.
However the functional test is unstable. In order to improve the CI
stability, this patch is removing this single test.

Closes-Bug: #2000163
Change-Id: I784b29e364d21d064ede233aa05a1f00079a4cae

commit_message:
Fix spelling of `ADITIONAL_VENV_PACKAGES`

This preserved `ADITIONAL_VENV_PACKAGES` as an input for backwards
compatiblity, but takes `ADDITIONAL_VENV_PACKAGES` with priority.

Fixes spelling in comment.

Related-Bug: #2046936
Change-Id: I84151d8f71b12da134e8fb9dbf3ae30f2a171fe2

Add the following to ``setup.cfg``:: [extract_messages] keywords = _ gettext ngettext l_ lazy_gettext mapping_file = babel.cfg output_file = ${MODULE_NAME}/locale/${MODULE_NAME}.pot [compile_catalog] directory = ${MODULE_NAME}/locale domain = ${MODULE_NAME} [update_catalog] domain = ${MODULE_NAME} output_dir = ${MODULE_NAME}/locale input_file = ${MODULE_NAME}/locale/${MODULE_NAME}.pot Note that ``${MODULE_NAME}`` is used in all names. Create ``babel.cfg`` with the following contents:: [python: **.py]

subject: Modify RGW client format
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2024-01-04 12:09:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/cbdb5ec6414df942f5cc8ed5b1e47438bc18cd1b', 'message': "Modify RGW client format

With changes to config_template module that restored usage of {% raw %} tags [1]
renderring of mapping keys, if they're defined as variables, was broken.

Ansible, by design [2], does not render mapping keys. Moreover, it was not
working as intended anyway, since renderring happened in post-copy stage
so same records were not merged together, which resulted in #1812245

As such behaviour is expected by Ansible design, instead of adding some
workaround in config_template module, I suggest working around issue
by defining troublesome mapping with Jinja, that will allow it to render properly.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ansible-config_template/+/881887
[2] https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/17324#issuecomment-685102595

Closes-Bug: #2048036

commit_message:
Modify RGW client format

With changes to config_template module that restored usage of {% raw %} tags [1]
renderring of mapping keys, if they're defined as variables, was broken.

Ansible, by design [2], does not render mapping keys. Moreover, it was not
working as intended anyway, since renderring happened in post-copy stage
so same records were not merged together, which resulted in #1812245

As such behaviour is expected by Ansible design, instead of adding some
workaround in config_template module, I suggest working around issue
by defining troublesome mapping with Jinja, that will allow it to render properly.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ansible-config_template/+/881887
[2] https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/17324#issuecomment-685102595

Closes-Bug: #2048036
Related-Bug: #1812245
Change-Id: I8a32736239c6326d817c620451799c13d5d8938c

commit_message:
Handle any error from libvirt operations

A review of the helper code which wraps libvirtmod's compiled
module which implements the libvirt wrapper for Python, which
we refer to and call as libvirt or python-libvirt, reveals that
it appears possible for AttributeError and KeyError to be raised
up to the intermediate library level. While everything else refers
to libvirtError, it still seems possible, albeit remote, that
the generated code and interactions may still raise exceptions
besides libvirtError which previously would result in unexpected
behavior.

What we sometimes see on the ipmitool side is a generic
"Error: Unable to establish IPMI v2 / RMCP+ session" error which
is generated in many cases, including when no response is received.

So, since libvirtError is based on an Exception class, changes
exception handling to just catch and log based upon Exception.

Change-Id: I8159f5d1de2acb0678e7c85306413fab6999e615

commit_message:
Add tox target and configuration for codespell

Adds a tox target for codespell, `tox -e codespell`. Can optionally
be run as `tox -e codespell -- -w` to get automatic spelling fixes
applied where appropriate. Adds small amounts of configuration to
setup.cfg, including an ignore list of words.

Related-bug: #2047654
Change-Id: I98203b02a9c6b6fc36edd6b4bbcc7c92a634da8b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-python-agent refs/changes/05/904405/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: [testenv:codespell] description = Run codespell to check spelling deps = codespell # note(JayF): {posargs} lets us run `tox -ecodespell -- -w` to get codespell # to correct spelling issues in our code it's aware of. commands = codespell {posargs}

Later changes in this chain will provide the codespell config used to
generate this, as well as adding this commit's SHA, once landed, to a
.git-blame-ignore-revs file to ensure it will not pollute git historys
for modern clients.

commit_message:
[codespell] Fix spelling issues in IPA

This fixes several spelling issues identified by codepsell. In some
cases, I may have manually modified a line to make the output more clear
or to correct grammatical issues which were obvious in the codespell
output.

Later changes in this chain will provide the codespell config used to
generate this, as well as adding this commit's SHA, once landed, to a
.git-blame-ignore-revs file to ensure it will not pollute git historys
for modern clients.

Related-Bug: 2047654
Change-Id: I240cf8484865c9b748ceb51f3c7b9fd973cb5ada

commit_message:
WIP: Use rich library

This is a test patch to play around with rendering the command line
shell output with the python rich library's table formatting.

https: //github.com/Textualize/rich
Change-Id: Ibf6e542a31905cc9daeeb9d40479763ec5090295
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-cinderclient refs/changes/31/844631/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from rich.console import Console from rich.table import Table console = Console() data = str(o[field]) data = str(getattr(o, field_name, '')) data = str(data.replace("\r", " ")) if objs: table_title = type(objs[0]).__name__ else: table_title = None table = Table(title=table_title, show_lines=False, safe_box=True) for f in fields: table.add_column(f) if order_by: # we have to sort the entire list by order_by column rows.sort(key=lambda x: x[sortby_index]) for row in rows: table.add_row(*row) console.print(table) # pt = prettytable.PrettyTable((f for f in fields), caching=False) # pt.align = 'l' # for row in rows: # count = 0 # # Converts unicode values in dictionary to string # for part in row: # count = count + 1 # if isinstance(part, dict): # row[count - 1] = part # pt.add_row(row) # # if sortby_index is None: # order_by = None # else: # order_by = fields[sortby_index] # _print(pt, order_by)def print_dict(d, property="Property", formatters=None): console = Console() if 'name' in d: table_title = f"[bold green]{d['name']}[/]" else: table_title = None table = Table(title=table_title, show_lines=False, safe_box=True) table.add_column(property) table.add_column("Value") for key in d: if type(d[key]) is dict: value = Table(show_lines=False, box=False) value.add_column(property) value.add_column("Value") if d[key]: for subkey in d[key]: value.add_row(subkey, str(d[key][subkey])) else: value = 'None' else: if key == "name": value = f"[bold green]{d[key]}[/]" else: value = str(d[key]) table.add_row(key, value) console.print(table) def print_dict_old(d, property="Property", formatters=None):
deleted_lines: data = o[field] data = getattr(o, field_name, '') data = data.replace("\r", " ") pt = prettytable.PrettyTable((f for f in fields), caching=False) pt.align = 'l' for row in rows: count = 0 # Converts unicode values in dictionary to string for part in row: count = count + 1 if isinstance(part, dict): row[count - 1] = part pt.add_row(row) _print(pt, order_by) def print_dict(d, property="Property", formatters=None):

commit_message:
Integrate Glare functionality

Add mechanism of using Glare links in Heat templates
and possibly Heat CLI.

blueprint integrate-with-glare

Change-Id: I137fb5f3bc4f4a97d8f960649197f94e6a4ad04d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-specs refs/changes/39/315439/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================= Integrate Glare functionality ============================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/integrate-with-glare Add mechanism of using Glare links to templates, environments and resources in Heat templates. Problem description =================== The main idea is to store template and environment files in storage (like Swift) and Glare will provide access to such files by links. We can use the templates directly through heat commands by providing link to template. But we also should use these links in Heat templates. For example, while we create nested stack. Proposed change =============== 1. Implement mechanism of using Glare links in template. 2. Create tests for new functionality. 3. Add documentation about new functionality. 4. Add some examples to heat-templates. Alternatives ------------ Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: ? (glare api hopefully will be provided in june) Work Items ---------- 1. Implement using of Glare links. 2. Add related tests. 3. Add corresponding docs. 4. Add examples of usage to heat-templates. Dependencies ============

commit_message:
WIP: Quota validation for whole template

Current Heat does not have any validation to check if the number of
requested resources exceeds the quota or not.
This might cause unexpected stack creation failures even though the
given resource parameters are good.
This proposal is aiming to add Quota validation which works for the
whole template to check if the sum of requested number & existing
number of each resource are not greater than the quota value.

Change-Id: I1d01dfeae2f2f9d4a9b6deef0289cb5c356dcfe2
Implements: blueprint quota-validation-whole-template
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-specs refs/changes/07/501107/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode .. This template should be in ReSTructured text. The filename in the git repository should match the launchpad URL, for example a URL of https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/awesome-thing should be named awesome-thing.rst . Please do not delete any of the sections in this template. If you have nothing to say for a whole section, just write: None For help with syntax, see http://sphinx-doc.org/rest.html To test out your formatting, see http://www.tele3.cz/jbar/rest/rest.html =================================== Quota validation for whole template =================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/quota-validation-whole-template Problem description =================== Current Heat does not have any validation to check if the number of requested resources exceeds the quota or not. This might cause unexpected stack creation failures even though the given resource parameters are good. Proposed change =============== Basic formula of this validation is here. ``requested number + existing number > quota`` * True => StackValidationFailed * False => Pass e.g. Stack creation along with a template including Nova instances * Number of requested Nova instances in a template: 9 * Number of existing Nova instances in the tenant: 2 * Allowed number of Nova instances by quota: 10 ``9 + 2 > 10`` => True, therefore Heat must raise StackValidationFailed Also more granular control should be implemented such that user can specify their own quota value per resources at heat.conf as artificial quota in Heat. heat.conf sample: .. code-block:: ini [quota_validation] os_nova_server = 10 os_nova_keypair = 100 os_neutron_net = 20 os_neutron_subnet = 20 os_neutron_port = 100 Resource type which should be in scope of this. * OS::Nova::Server * OS::Nova::KeyPair * OS::Nova::floatingip Alternatives ------------ None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: kazsh Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: queens-1 Work Items ---------- * Add a new module(heat/engine/quota_validation.py) * Improve the validate() method in heat.engine.stack module to run the newly added quota validation logic * Add new parameters(heat/common/common.py) * Add required unit tests Dependencies ============ None

commit_message:
Add a solution to support server health monitoring, both including Ceilometer and Monasca

Change-Id: I8775e67819b3d0982b097834d4acf983062e5e71
buleprint support-server-health-monitoring-solution
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-specs refs/changes/06/175706/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================== Support server health monitoring solution based on Monasca =========================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/support-server-health-monitoring-solution This design support a server health monitoring solution by providing a list of preconfigured actions you can associate with an alarm. So it defines action policy and execute the actual action defined in this policy. This action policy is related to an alarm generated by Monasca. And this action will be triggered after an alarm generated. So what is Monasca? Monasca is a open-source multi-tenant, highly scalable, performance, fault-tolerant monitoring-as-a-service solution that integrates with OpenStack. It uses a REST API for high-speed metrics processing and querying and has a streaming alarm engine and notification engine. Problem description =================== Currently in Monasca, when alarm state transforms, the post-processing operation is only to send SMS or Email to subscriber. There is no customized operations available to users that can automatically process some useful actions inside the server So this design provides some action policies that can be customized by user. These action policies are operations that occur in response to triggered alarms. For example, vm reset is alarm action. For example, when a physical machine in Openstack cluster is overheat and generates an alarm. it only can send the sms or email to administrator to make decision what to do next without this design. But now the system will trigger the corrective actions if customized by user used this design. As per corrective actions defines, All the vms on this physical machine will be migrated to others and this physcal machine will be erased from this Openstack cluster. Proposed change =============== Design specification: This design provides a list of preconfigured actions you can associate with an alarm. It can be customized by users. 1) Actions for physical machine (ironic node or host): * Power on * Power off * Enter maintenance mode * Exit maintenance mode * ... 2) Action for virtual machine (instance): * Power on * Power off * Suspend * Reset * Migrate * ... 3) Action including both physical machine and virtual machine * Migrate vm and power off physical machine (ironic node) Certainly, preconfigured alarm actions can consist of both for physical machine and virtual machine. For example, migrate the virtual machine and put the physical machine in maintenance mode. Alarm actions for virtual machines include powering on, powering off, and suspending the virtual machine. Although the actions are preconfigured, you must manually set up certain aspects of the action, Some alarm actions require additional configuration, such as instance ID or ironic node ID. Change points: 1) Ironic client plugin will be added for communication with Ironic as we support the physical machine action including ironic node. 2) Add the OS::Heat::MonitorActionPolicy resource which execute the actual action policy, This resource is compatibility with Ceilometer or Monasca alarms. heat_template_version: 2013-05-23 resource: monitor_action_policy: type: OS::Heat::MonitorActionPolicy properties: monitor_type: String action: String instance_id: String ironic_node_id: String ---- Properties: monitor_type: Monitor type which the monitor action policy is assigned to. Type: String Required property Constraints: {'ironic node','instance', 'both'} monitor_action: The actual action which the monitor action policy is defined to. Type: String Required property Constraints: {'ironic node power on','ironic node power off','ironic node enter maintenance mode','ironic node exit maintenance mode', Migrate vm and power off physical machine 'instance power on', 'instance power off','instance suspend', 'instance migrate', 'instance reset'} instance_id: Instance ID to which the monitor action policy do the actual action. Type: String While monitor_type is "ironic node", this isn't need to be defined. While monitor_type is "instance", this is required property. ironic_node_id: Ironic node ID to which the monitor action policy do the actual action. Type: String While monitor_type is "ironic node", this isn't need to be defined. While monitor_type is "instance", this is required property. Attributes alarm_url A signed url to handle the alarm. Hot Syntax example: heat_template_version: 2013-05-23 ... resources: ... monitor_action: type: OS::Heat::MonitorActionPolicy properties: monitor_type: ironic node monitor_action: ironic node power on ironic_node_id: xxxxx 3) Add Monasca Alarm and Notification definition resource plugin OS::Monasca::Alarm and OS::Monasca::Notification It depends on another blueprint defined the Monasca alarm/notification plugin in heat. The blueprint url is https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/support-monasca-alarm-notification. 4) User scenario example of this design is as below (monitor_action.yaml) This scenario example is under cloud infrastructure system with ironic nodes. * Once the system detects temperature over-heat (i.e., temperature is over than or equal to 90 degrees) more than 3 times, The system will send the monasca notification to trigger corrective actions. * At the same time, the system will also trigger the corrective actions if specified. The corrective action is specified as transfer a vm to another compute node. * vms on this node will be transferred to another compute node monitor_action.yaml heat_template_version: 2013-05-23 parameters: instance_id: type: string label: Instance ID default: None description: Instance ID which will be migrated. ironic_node_id: type: string label: Ironic Node ID default: None description: Ironic Node which will be powered off. resources: monitor_action: type: OS::Heat::MonitorActionPolicy properties: monitor_type: both monitor_action: Migrate vm and power off physical machine ironic_node_id: { get_param: ironic_node_id } instance_id: { get_param: instance_id } monasca_notification: type: OS::Monasca::Alarm properties: name: test_notification type: webhook address: { get_attr: [monitor_action, alarm_url] } monasca_alarm: type: OS::Monasca::Alarm properties: expression: avg(cpu.temperature{hostname=mini_mon}) > 90 time 3 match_by: mini-mon serverity: CRITICAL alarm_actions: - { get_resource: monasca_notification} In the template, described above, workflow will begin execute when alarm will goes to the state 'alarm'. Alternatives ------------ None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <hongyefang> Assisted by: Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: TDM Work Items ---------- * Add OS::Heat::MonitorActionPolicy resource * Add ironic client plugin for Heat * Add OS::Monasca::Alarm and OS::Monasca::Notification resource * Add heat hot template for MonitorActionPolicy Dependencies ============ None

commit_message:
Migrate to use glance v2

Now glance v1 is deprecated, and even in devstack the
default version of glance is v2, this blueprint will migrate
to use glance v2, and will make image resource compatible
with old template.

Change-Id: I80ca7131a705e08925588cb2b92e4a75cd5c8242
Blueprint: migrate-to-glance-v2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-specs refs/changes/50/240450/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ====================== Migrate to glance v2 ====================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/migrate-to-glance-v2 Migrate to use glance v2, and make template of glance image resource compatible with glance v2. Problem description =================== Now glance v1 is deprecated, and even in devstack the default version of glance is v2, also consider that there are some glance v2 resources which we may want to support in heat, so we will migrate to use glance v2. Proposed change =============== We will migrate to use glance v2, and will to make glance resources(now only one resource: image) compatible with old template. There are two differences between v1 and v2 for image resource: 1. The glance v1 supports to set 'location' in image-create api, but glance v2 provides another location-add api instead. Solution: set the 'location' after an empty image creation. 2. The glance v1 supports to specify whether the image is public when image creation with 'is_public' parameter, glance v2 use 'visibility' parameter instead. Solution: add new property 'visibility', set support status 'deprecated' for property 'is_public', and make the two property mutually exclusive. Alternatives ------------ None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: huangtianhua@huawei.com Milestones ---------- mitaka-1 Work Items ---------- 1. Modify the glance client to v2. 2. Make sure the image resource compatible with old template. 3. Add related tests. Dependencies ============ None

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-specs refs/changes/26/443426/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================= Heat Freezer Resource ========================= bp: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/freezer/+spec/freezer-resource Add resource which enable heat to interact directly with the Freezer API, which allow to backup some resource for OpenStack with Heat. Problem description =================== Freezer provider an API which is used for the purposes of distributed backup restore and disaster recovery, such that it can backup nova_instance and cinder_volume in the OpenStack cloud platform. Use Cases --------- * For End User it will allow you to create a backup and restore action, and job directly using heat template Proposed change =============== Implement new resource type. * Add Freezer action and job resources * OS::Freezer::Client * OS::Freezer::BackupAction * OS::Freezer::RestoreAction * OS::Freezer::AdminAction * OS::Freezer::Job * OS::Freezer::Session For these types will be used following metadata structure: Example for BackupAction type: Required Properties ------------------- backup_name: Descriptive name of the backup String Value cinder_vol_id or cindernative_vol_id: The uuid of cinder-volume. String Value Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- Example for Job: * OS:Freezer::Job * properties * job_name * schedule_start_date * scheduler_end_date * schedule_interval REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ------------- Milestones ---------- pike-1 Work Items ---------- * Add a case for volume BackupAction, RestoreAction resources * Add Job resource * Create heat templates * Add document Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= None Documentation Impact ==================== None

subject: Adding Optional Health to OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-09-29 02:31:40.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat-specs/commit/73d624a3744ef907f26dda860a750145a9f3ab85', 'message': 'Spec for AutoScalingGroup with Health Maintenance

To cope with lack of promise of reasonable transition period when
HARestarter is removed, defines OS::Heat::AutoScalingHealthyGroup, to
be a subclass of OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup that adds health
maintenance for members based on health as determined by an
OS::Neutron::Pool. This is implementable now, and should be
implementable when OS::Heat::HARestarter is replaced with something
else.

This spec follows a revised approach that has no dependency (unlike
the first approach).

Change-Id: I9a76b5e7610c7f5b6f798ea7e03788f8a731157e
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-09-29 04:32:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat-specs/commit/715a78075a70287d3d72c353257a3435c239ada8', 'message': 'Spec for AutoScalingGroup with Health Maintenance

To cope with lack of promise of reasonable transition period when
HARestarter is removed, defines OS::Heat::AutoScalingHealthyGroup, to
be a subclass of OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup that adds health
maintenance for members based on health as determined by an
OS::Neutron::Pool. This is implementable now, and should be
implementable when OS::Heat::HARestarter is replaced with something
else.

This spec follows a revised approach that has no dependency (unlike
the first approach).

Change-Id: I9a76b5e7610c7f5b6f798ea7e03788f8a731157e
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2014-10-14 22:31:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat-specs/commit/f3516d36b21c6cb70c95b0efcb1880d26c1d2db7', 'message': 'Adding Optional Health to OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup

The motivation for introducing this change is the lack of positive
affirmation in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/121824/ that there
will be a reasonable transition period during which both
``OS::Heat::HARestarter`` and some newer better alternative are
available.  You can also see in the discussion in
http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/heat/2014/heat.2014-10-01-12.01.log.html
a desire to keep open the possibility that HARestarter will be removed
without a 1 release transition period.  The proposed change is to
introduce, at least 1 release before HARestarter is removed, a wrapper
that (a) obscures the use of HARestarter, (b) has an interface that is
narrow enough that we are confident that it will be reasonable to
implement in the not clearly seen future, (c) has enough functionality
that current users of HARestarer can use the wrapper instead.  In
addition to those three sharp criteria, there is also a desire to make
the wrapper be something that we would be comfortable with users using
indefinitely, not just to smooth over a transition away from
HARestarter.  This enables current users to switch to using the
wrapper over a transtion period of at least 1 release before
HARestarter is removed.  Once users have made this transition, we can
remove HARestarter and change the implementation behind the wrapper
simultaneously without disturbing users.

This is the spec for
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/autoscaling-healthy-group

Change-Id: I9a76b5e7610c7f5b6f798ea7e03788f8a731157e
'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2014-10-15 20:37:12.000000000', 'files': ['specs/juno/autoscaling-healthy-group.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat-specs/commit/74d0ec937e20a302f6173802bd4981eba9cb0f0b', 'message': "Adding Optional Health to OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup

Currently it is possible to write a Heat template that prescribes a
set of virtual resources with health maintenance, using the health
determinations made by Neutron's LBaaS.  While it is possible, it is
ugly.  The user is required to write a bunch of mechanism for each
thing that the user wants maintained.  There is no way for a user or a
cloud operator to write a template resource (formerly known as a
provider template) that implements this abstraction.  In contrast,
some other IaaS platforms have health maintenance as a built-in part
of the functionality of their scaling groups.  The proposed change is
to generalize ``OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup`` so that it can optionally
maintain member health as determined by LBaaS.  Note that LBaaS has
health checking functionality that does not require any actual
application traffic to be load balanced.  The goal here is not to
attempt fully general health maintenance, only to cover common cases
--- with an interface that we think is reasonable to use and does not
paint ourselves into a corner regarding future implementations.  It
just so happens that all of the users I know to be wanting health
maintenance will be satisfied with this generalization of
``OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup`` --- and be happy to use it instead of
repeating a bunch of mechanism using ``OS::Heat::HARestarter`` and/or
other stuff --- supposing the relevant schedulers do not keep putting
guests on broken hosts (which is really a separate problem).

This is the spec for
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/autoscaling-healthy-group

Change-Id: I9a76b5e7610c7f5b6f798ea7e03788f8a731157e
"}]
commit_message:
Adding Optional Health to OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup

Currently it is possible to write a Heat template that prescribes a
set of virtual resources with health maintenance, using the health
determinations made by Neutron's LBaaS.  While it is possible, it is
ugly.  The user is required to write a bunch of mechanism for each
thing that the user wants maintained.  There is no way for a user or a
cloud operator to write a template resource (formerly known as a
provider template) that implements this abstraction.  In contrast,
some other IaaS platforms have health maintenance as a built-in part
of the functionality of their scaling groups.  The proposed change is
to generalize ``OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup`` so that it can optionally
maintain member health as determined by LBaaS.  Note that LBaaS has
health checking functionality that does not require any actual
application traffic to be load balanced.  The goal here is not to
attempt fully general health maintenance, only to cover common cases
--- with an interface that we think is reasonable to use and does not
paint ourselves into a corner regarding future implementations.  It
just so happens that all of the users I know to be wanting health
maintenance will be satisfied with this generalization of
``OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup`` --- and be happy to use it instead of
repeating a bunch of mechanism using ``OS::Heat::HARestarter`` and/or
other stuff --- supposing the relevant schedulers do not keep putting
guests on broken hosts (which is really a separate problem).

This is the spec for
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/autoscaling-healthy-group

Change-Id: I9a76b5e7610c7f5b6f798ea7e03788f8a731157e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-specs refs/changes/56/124656/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================================================== AutoScalingGroup with Health Maintenance for Members ==================================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/autoscaling-healthy-group The motivation for introducing this special kind of scaling group is the lack of positive affirmation in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/121824/ that there will be a reasonable transition period during which both ``OS::Heat::HARestarter`` and some newer better alternative are available. If we make ``AutoScalingHealthyGroup`` available for a reasonable transition period before the abrupt removal of HARestarter and for another reasonable transition period thereafter then users of health maintenance will not have to cope with an abrupt change. Problem description =================== The problem is that users want health maintenance now and it is possible now but only using a resource type (``OS::Heat::HARestarter``) that is slated for apparently abrupt replacement with something else. The health in question is not just the existence of the backing resource but also its proper functioning. OpenStack already has a standard way of testing that, it is prescribed by an ``OS::Neutron::HealthMonitor``. So the problem is to provide an interim resource type that (a) covers the common cases of health maintenance and (b) is implementable both using ``HARestarter`` and whatever else will become available when ``HARestarter`` is deleted. It is not logically necessary to bundle health maintenance with scaling group membership but this was done to cope with the possibility that the replacement for ``HARestarter`` first becomes available only for scaling group members. Today it is possible for a health maintenance solution to trigger reaction on a wide variety of conditions --- anything you can program in Ceilometer. This new scaling group was chosen to have a narrower set of possiblities because (a) it makes the interface simpler and (b) it is less likely to be made difficult by future changes. Proposed change =============== The proposed change is to introduce a subclass of ``OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup``, named ``OS::Heat::AutoScalingHealthyGroup``, that adds health maintenance of each member. We allow an arbitrary Heat resource specification for a member, but the group requires some cooperation from each member. Each member must include an OS::Neutron::PoolMember that connects the member to an OS::Neutron::Pool that has an associated OS::Neutron::HealthMonitor that prescribes how the health of the member is checked. Each member must also have an attribute that reveals the ID of that OS::Neutron::PoolMember. The ``OS::Heat::AutoScalingHealthyGroup`` has a property, named ``pool_member_attribute_name``, that is given the name of that member attribute. We also add a ``timeout_in_minutes`` property, analogous to the ``TimeoutInMinutes`` property of ``AWS::CloudFormation::Stack``. A new Heat configuration variable is introduced, to indicate the cloud provider's choice of sample averaging period used in reacting to health samples from LBaaS. Since the cloud provider is in charge of the sampling rate, it is appropriate for him to be in charge of the averaging period too. Like other resource types, this new one will reside in ``heat/engine/resources``. Alternatives ------------ I considered making the user metadata item name a variable, but that made the implementation diverge even further from what could be done with a provider template --- which I hope to eventually do (even though it can not be done today). I initially proposed introducing a resource type for a nested stack whose template is the value of a property. I switched to effectively generating a file because I suspect that will be easier to implement. Implementation ============== The implementation will override the ``_get_instance_definition`` method of ``OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup`` and also generate a (file name, file contents) pair to add to the set used when creating the nested stack from the generated template. The ``ResourceDefinition`` returned by the modified ``_get_instance_definition`` method will correspond to the following YAML. Each double-quoted string describes the value that the code will put in the string's place. Also, in the cases where an optional property is omitted, the corresponding part of the YAML below will be omitted. .. code-block:: yaml type: AWS::CloudFormation::Stack properties: TimeoutInMinutes: "value of ASHG's timeout_in_minutes property" TemplateURL: "some generated URL for the associated generated file" Following are the contents generated for the associated file contents. Remember, no actual file is generated; the contents are directly associated with the file name in the generated ``Template``. Again, a double-quoted string describes the value that the code puts in the string's position. .. code-block:: yaml heat_template_version: 2013-05-23 description: member with health maintenance resources: thing: "value of ASHG's resource property" restarter: type: OS::Heat::HARestarter properties: InstanceID: {get_resource: thing} alarm: type: OS::Ceilometer::Alarm properties: description: react if LB thinks thing is unhealthy meter_name: network.services.lb.member statistic: avg period: "value of health_avg_period config" comparison_operator: lt threshold: 0.4 evaluation_periods: 1 alarm_actions: [{quote: {get_attr: [restarter, AlarmUrl]} }] matching_metadata: resource: get_attr: - {get_resource: thing} - "value of ASHG's pool_member_attribute_name prop" outputs: restart_url: value: {get_attr: [restarter, AlarmUrl]} description: FOR DEBUG ONLY. Webhook of the restarter. ceilometer_query: value: str_replace: template: ceilometer statistics -m network.services.lb.member -q resource=memberid -p period -a avg params: memberid: get_attr: - {get_resource: thing} - "value of ASHG's pool_member_attribute_name prop" period: "value of health_avg_period config" description: This is a Ceilometer CLI command that produces statistics similar to those used by the alarm Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: mike-spreitzer Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: Juno Work Items ---------- No decomposition identified. Dependencies ============ No dependency on another blueprint or change. This has no dependency on code outside OpenStack.

commit_message:
Adds template for Wordpress using neutron services

Template to deploys 2 instances wordpress (app server separated from db server)
using Neutron LBaaS to provide HA, FWaaS to limit network access and VPNaaS to
provide secure connection between application servers and database server.

Change-Id: I8f0845179f600064961d28ca2661f17acf188dbf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-templates refs/changes/96/58496/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

", "systemctl restart httpd.service
" ]]}} } }, "AppServer2" : { "Type" : "OS::Nova::Server", "Properties" : { "image" : { "Fn::FindInMap" : [ "OpenstackRegion2Image", "RegionOne", { "Ref" : "LinuxDistribution" } ] }, "flavor" : { "Ref" : "InstanceType" }, "key_name" : { "Ref" : "KeyName" }, "networks" : [ { "port": { "Ref" : "Port2" } } ], "user_data" : { "Fn::Base64" : { "Fn::Join" : ["", [ "#!/bin/bash -v

", "firewall-cmd --add-service=http

", "sed -i "s/Require local/Require all granted/" /etc/httpd/conf.d/wordpress.conf
", "sed --in-place --e s/database_name_here/", { "Ref" : "DBName" }, "/ --e s/username_here/", { "Ref" : "DBUsername" }, "/ --e s/password_here/", { "Ref" : "DBPassword" }, "/ --e s/localhost/", { "Fn::GetAtt" : [ "DBServer", "first_address" ]}, "/ /usr/share/wordpress/wp-config.php
", "systemctl restart httpd.service
" ]]}} } }, "LBMonitor" : { "Type": "OS::Neutron::HealthMonitor", "Properties" : { "type" : "HTTP", "expected_codes" : "200, 301", "url_path" : "/wordpress", "delay" : 3, "max_retries" : 5, "timeout" : 10 } }, "LBPool": { "Type" : "OS::Neutron::Pool", "Properties" : { "protocol" : "HTTP", "subnet_id" : { "Ref" : "Subnet1" }, "lb_method" : "ROUND_ROBIN", "vip" : { "address" : { "Ref" : "LBIPAddress" }, "protocol_port" : 80 }, "monitors" : [ { "Ref" : "LBMonitor" } ] } }, "LB": { "Type": "OS::Neutron::LoadBalancer", "Properties" : { "protocol_port" : 80, "pool_id" : { "Ref" : "LBPool"}, "members" : [ { "Ref" : "AppServer1" }, { "Ref" : "AppServer2" } ] } }, "Firewall": { "Type" : "OS::Neutron::Firewall", "Properties" : { "firewall_policy_id" : { "Ref" : "FirewallPolicy" }, "admin_state_up" : true } }, "FirewallPolicy": { "Type": "OS::Neutron::FirewallPolicy", "Properties" : { "firewall_rules" : [ { "Ref" : "FirewallRuleAnyToLB" }, { "Ref" : "FirewallRuleLBToApps" }, { "Ref" : "FirewallRuleAppsToAny" }, { "Ref" : "FirewallRuleDBToAny" }, { "Ref" : "FirewallRuleOtherwiseDeny" } ] } }, "FirewallRuleAnyToLB" : { "Type" : "OS::Neutron::FirewallRule", "Properties" : { "destination_ip_address" : { "Ref" : "LBIPAddress" }, "action" : "allow", "enabled" : true, "ip_version" : "4" } }, "FirewallRuleLBToApps" : { "Type" : "OS::Neutron::FirewallRule", "Properties" : { "source_ip_address" : { "Ref" : "LBIPAddress" }, "destination_ip_address" : { "Ref" : "SubnetCidr1" }, "action" : "allow", "enabled" : true, "ip_version" : "4" } }, "FirewallRuleAppsToAny" : { "Type" : "OS::Neutron::FirewallRule", "Properties" : { "source_ip_address" : { "Ref" : "SubnetCidr1" }, "action" : "allow", "enabled" : true, "ip_version" : "4" } }, "FirewallRuleDBToAny" : { "Type" : "OS::Neutron::FirewallRule", "Properties" : { "source_ip_address" : { "Ref" : "SubnetCidr2" }, "action" : "allow", "enabled" : true, "ip_version" : "4" } }, "FirewallRuleOtherwiseDeny" : { "Type" : "OS::Neutron::FirewallRule", "Properties" : { "action" : "deny", "enabled" : true, "ip_version" : "4" } } }, "Outputs" : { "SubnetId" : { "Description" : "Subnet Id", "Value" : { "Ref" : "Subnet1" } } } }

commit_message:
Verify certificates when makeing https request to cfn api

This patch gets the verify_cert parameter from the environment
set by the os-collect-config and use it to pass to the requests
libraray to verify certificates when making https request to heat
cfn api server.

Change-Id: Ib3572759bb9a12d65abbba521e48af0eb17ff396
Depends-On: I4f6262967ad346c6ff103cb359b02b81ef71573f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-templates refs/changes/57/285157/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # OCC_HTTPS_VERIFY is set by os-collect-config to verify the certs # if ca_certificate is passed to os-collect-config else ignore it. verify_cert = os.environ.get('OCC_HTTPS_VERIFY', True) if verify_cert == 'True': verify_cert = True if verify_cert == 'False': verify_cert = False headers={'content-type': None}, verify=verify_cert) headers={'content-type': None}, verify=verify_cert)

commit_message:
Update hot/autoscaling.yaml to use query property

Following https://review.openstack.org/#/c/127821/ .
Replaced usage of matching_metadata with usage of
the query property on an OS::Ceilometer::Alarm.

Change-Id: If0004a1d181107630ea481439c0515f44c244e3e

commit_message:
Sample template using SoftwareDeployments

This template demonstrates how to use SoftwareDeployments over a group
of servers.  The key points of this template are:

 - the use of '2014-10-16' as the version, or else 'get_attr' won't work
   as expected.
 - the approach to generate 'servers' property for SoftwareDeployments.
 - passing dictionary into server and extract info corresponding to
   current server.

Change-Id: I632799221d42c3e133ee1d162686cb234bd9d549
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-templates refs/changes/49/134749/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: heat_template_version: 2014-10-16 description: > A template showing how to deploy softare config to a group of servers. parameters: image: type: string key_name: type: string flavor: type: string default: m1.small count: type: number resources: shared_config: type: OS::Heat::SoftwareConfig properties: group: script inputs: - name: CUSTOM_ENV1 type: String config: | #!/bin/python import os import datetime print(datetime.datetime.utcnow()) print(os.environ.get('deploy_project_id')) print(os.environ.get('deploy_stack_id')) print(os.environ.get('deploy_resource_name')) print(os.environ.get('deploy_auth_url')) print(os.environ.get('deploy_username')) print(os.environ.get('deploy_user_id')) print(os.environ.get('deploy_password')) print(os.environ.get('CUSTOM_ENV1')) exit(0) deploys: type: OS::Heat::SoftwareDeployments properties: signal_transport: HEAT_SIGNAL input_values: CUSTOM_ENV1: A input value servers: {get_attr: [servers, attributes, show, id]} config: {get_resource: shared_config } servers: type: OS::Heat::ResourceGroup properties: count: {get_param: count} resource_def: type: OS::Nova::Server properties: name: server_%index% image: { get_param: image} key_name: { get_param: key_name } flavor: { get_param: flavor } user_data_format: SOFTWARE_CONFIG outputs: d_outs: value: {get_attr: [deploys, deploy_stdouts]} d_errors: value: {get_attr: [deploys, deploy_stderrs]} d_codes: value: {get_attr: [deploys, deploy_status_codes]} server_list: value: {get_attr: [servers, attributes, show, id]}

commit_message:
Examples that test scaling across AZs

These examples exercise the support for spreading scaling groups
across availability zones.  See
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/116139/ for the change that adds that
support.

Change-Id: I17e49c9437f3e6f28c1e79036aa477c95b3f7fbf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-templates refs/changes/58/116558/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: heat_template_version: 2013-05-23 description: > This is a very simple template that illustrates the basic features of OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup when the scaled resource is an OS::Nova::Server. By virtue of its simplicity this example should be usable in many contexts. In particular, this example does not require Neutron nor a load balancer nor any particular support for software in the VMs. In fact, the VMs in this example do not actually do anything. This example does no automatic scaling, but does discuss manual scaling. For a more complete example, see autoscaling.yaml. parameters: key_name: type: string description: Name of an existing key pair to use for the instances constraints: - custom_constraint: nova.keypair description: Must name a public key (pair) known to Nova flavor: type: string description: Flavor for the instances to be created default: m1.small constraints: - custom_constraint: nova.flavor description: Must be a flavor known to Nova image: type: string description: > Name or ID of the image to use for the instances. You can get the default from http://cloud.fedoraproject.org/fedora-20.x86_64.qcow2 There is also http://cloud.fedoraproject.org/fedora-20.i386.qcow2 Any image should work since this template does not ask the VMs to do anything. constraints: - custom_constraint: glance.image description: Must identify an image known to Glance network: type: string description: The network for the VM default: private resources: my_asg: type: OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup properties: availability_zones: {"Fn::GetAZs": ""} resource: type: OS::Nova::Server properties: key_name: { get_param: key_name } image: { get_param: image } flavor: { get_param: flavor } networks: [{network: {get_param: network} }] min_size: 1 desired_capacity: 3 max_size: 10 scale_up_policy: type: OS::Heat::ScalingPolicy properties: adjustment_type: change_in_capacity auto_scaling_group_id: {get_resource: my_asg} cooldown: 60 scaling_adjustment: 1 scale_down_policy: type: OS::Heat::ScalingPolicy properties: adjustment_type: change_in_capacity auto_scaling_group_id: {get_resource: my_asg} cooldown: 60 scaling_adjustment: '-1' outputs: scale_up_url: description: > This URL is the webhook to scale up the group. You can invoke the scale-up operation by doing an HTTP POST to this URL; no body nor extra headers are needed. value: {get_attr: [scale_up_policy, alarm_url]} scale_dn_url: description: > This URL is the webhook to scale down the group. You can invoke the scale-down operation by doing an HTTP POST to this URL; no body nor extra headers are needed. value: {get_attr: [scale_down_policy, alarm_url]}

added_lines: "EC", None, None, 'secp256r1') ) self.assertTrue( self.plugin.supports( plugin.PluginSupportTypes.ASYMMETRIC_KEY_GENERATION, "EC", None, None, 'SOMETHING_RANDOM') ) self.assertFalse( self.plugin.supports( plugin.PluginSupportTypes.ASYMMETRIC_KEY_GENERATION, def test_generate_secp256r1_EC_key_with_passphrase(self): generate_dto = plugin.GenerateDTO('ec', None, None, 'changeme', 'secp256r1') kek_meta_dto = self._get_mocked_kek_meta_dto() private_dto, public_dto, passwd_dto = self.plugin.generate_asymmetric( generate_dto, kek_meta_dto, mock.MagicMock() ) decrypt_dto = plugin.DecryptDTO(private_dto.cypher_text) private_dto = self.plugin.decrypt(decrypt_dto, kek_meta_dto, private_dto.kek_meta_extended, mock.MagicMock()) decrypt_dto = plugin.DecryptDTO(public_dto.cypher_text) public_dto = self.plugin.decrypt(decrypt_dto, kek_meta_dto, public_dto.kek_meta_extended, mock.MagicMock()) # check we can reload the private and public keys private_key = serialization.load_pem_private_key( data=private_dto, password='changeme'.encode(), backend=default_backend() ) public_key = serialization.load_pem_public_key( data=public_dto, backend=default_backend() ) public_key = public_key.public_bytes( encoding=serialization.Encoding.DER, format=serialization.PublicFormat.SubjectPublicKeyInfo ) # get the public key from the private key we recovered to compare recovered_key = private_key.public_key().public_bytes( encoding=serialization.Encoding.DER, format=serialization.PublicFormat.SubjectPublicKeyInfo ) self.assertTrue(public_key == recovered_key)

commit_message:
Improve Blazar integration with Nova

As of today we do not have any means of Blazar integration with Nova,
while we do provide roles for Blazar installation for a while now. This
patch aims to bring in more native integration and remove necessity
of overrides for such deployment.

Related-Bug: #2048048
Co-Authored-By: Alexey Rusetsky <fenuks@fenuks.ru>
Change-Id: Ica50a5504de1b1604f72123751cbb3f45c85ab46

commit_message:
Catch race condition with multiple secret stores enabled

Catches the ConstraintCheck exception thrown in
barbican/model/repositories.py line 425.
This also contains modifications to use one session in
order to perform all db operations as a transaction that
is rolled back in barbican/model/repositories.py:422

Change-Id: I175d2c73e57d85a3e9288116db8fc72bc871e883
Closes-bug: 2043457

commit_message:
WIP adding Image encryption parameters

For the image encryption a new container_format 'encrypted' is added.
A validation for additionally required parameters is added for the
image creation. Registering and unregistering as a secret consumer
for the key of the encrypted image is added, but still misses the
complete implementation in Barbican and Castellan.

Change-Id: Iab99a77236a9a1eb765ec8e93f12128cc87530ce
Co-Authored-By: Markus Hentsch <markus.hentsch@secustack.com>

commit_message:
Add encryption and decryption for files for Image Encryption

Encryption and decryption of encrypted Images need to happen in
several places in OpenStack when encrypted Images are handled. The
methods are added to the os_brick.file_crypto module to be available
to Cinder and an OpenStackclient-plugin first, and in the future
these may also be used in Nova.

Co-Authored-By: Markus Hentsch <markus.hentsch@secustack.com>
Co-Authored-By: Josephine Seifert <josephine.seifert@secustack.com>

Implements: blueprint brick-gpg-encryption-support

Change-Id: I10559fd31f6bab70507ef09f4161f30fd9067b7b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-brick refs/changes/32/709432/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2020 OpenStack Foundation # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from os_brick.file_crypto.drivers.gpg import GpgFileEncryptor def get_file_encryptor(crypto_type, crypto_provider, crypto_cipher): """Get file encryptor object matching the given cipher properties. Selects and instantiates the appropriate encryptor class object which matches the encryption criteria as specified via the cipher properties. :param crypto_type: Type of the cipher, either "asymmetric" or "symmetric". :type crypto_type: string :param crypto_provider: Identifier of the encryption provider. :type crypto_provider: string :param crypto_cipher: Cipher algorithm name. :type crypto_cipher: string """ if crypto_type == 'symmetric': if crypto_provider == 'GPG': if crypto_cipher == 'AES256': return GpgFileEncryptor(cipher_algo='AES256') else: msg = ("GPG does not support encryption cipher %s" % crypto_cipher) raise ValueError(msg) else: msg = ("Unsupported encryption provider %s" % crypto_provider) raise ValueError(msg) else: msg = ("Unsupported encryption type %s" % crypto_type) raise ValueError(msg) def get_file_encryptor_for_image(image_properties): """Get image encryptor object matching the given image properties. Selects and instantiates the appropriate image encryptor class object which matches the encryption criteria as specified via the image properties. :param image_properties: Image metadata properties including encryption parameters, such as type, provider and cipher. :type image_properties: dict """ def _get_property(prop): if prop not in image_properties: msg = ("Image property %s missing from input" % prop) raise KeyError(msg) else: return image_properties[prop] crypto_type = _get_property('encryption_type') crypto_provider = _get_property('encryption_provider') crypto_cipher = _get_property('encryption_cipher') return get_file_encryptor(crypto_type, crypto_provider, crypto_cipher)

commit_message:
Handle creation of Port_Binding with chassis set

When there is a backlog of notifications to be sent, it is possible
that ovsdb-server will merge insert and update notifications. Due
to this, we need to handle the situation where we see a Port_Binding
created with the chassis set.

Closes-Bug: #2017748

Change-Id: Idfae87cf6c60e9e18ede91ea20857cea5322738c
(cherry picked from commit a641e8aec09c1e33a15a34b19d92675ed2c85682)

added_lines: events = (self.ROW_CREATE, self.ROW_UPDATE,) (event == self.ROW_CREATE or not old.chassis))

commit_message:
Handle creation of Port_Binding with chassis set

When there is a backlog of notifications to be sent, it is possible
that ovsdb-server will merge insert and update notifications. Due
to this, we need to handle the situation where we see a Port_Binding
created with the chassis set.

Closes-Bug: #2017748

Change-Id: Idfae87cf6c60e9e18ede91ea20857cea5322738c
(cherry picked from commit a641e8aec09c1e33a15a34b19d92675ed2c85682)

commit_message:
Add backwards compatibility of ceph_components format

With [1] we have broken compatibility of potentially provided extra components
config without any notice.

In order to handle this now we fix backwards compatibility along with
adding a deprecation note on the format of ``client``.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible-ceph_client/+/882827

Closes-Bug: #2047783
Change-Id: I89b67f0f0545d799194d8486a6bb25227279af84

commit_message:
sq: tolerate x-backend-record-shard-format=nonsense

Default to returning x-backend-record-shard-format=full if the request
header value is nonsense.

Change-Id: I172690fd4e966354d96f0c7e4606f3d9d1252106
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/40/904840/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.assertIn('X-Backend-Record-Shard-Format', resp.headers) self.assertEqual( 'full', resp.headers['X-Backend-Record-Shard-Format']) self.assertIn('X-Backend-Record-Shard-Format', resp.headers) self.assertEqual( 'full', resp.headers['X-Backend-Record-Shard-Format']) def test_GET_shard_ranges_with_format_header(self): # verify that shard range GET defaults to the 'full' format sr = self._populate_container('/sda1/p/a/c') def do_test(headers): headers.update({'X-Timestamp': next(self.ts).internal, 'X-Backend-Record-Type': 'shard'}) req = Request.blank( '/sda1/p/a/c', environ={'REQUEST_METHOD': 'GET'}, headers=headers, params={'format': 'json'}) resp = req.get_response(self.controller) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 200) self.assertEqual([dict(sr, last_modified=sr.timestamp.isoformat)], json.loads(resp.body)) self.assertIn('X-Backend-Record-Type', resp.headers) self.assertEqual('shard', resp.headers['X-Backend-Record-Type']) self.assertIn('X-Backend-Record-Shard-Format', resp.headers) self.assertEqual( 'full', resp.headers['X-Backend-Record-Shard-Format']) do_test({}) do_test({'X-Backend-Record-Shard-Format': ''}) do_test({'X-Backend-Record-Shard-Format': 'full'}) do_test({'X-Backend-Record-Shard-Format': 'nonsense'})

commit_message:
[OVN] Remove backwards compatibility with OVN < v20.09 ver 2

This is a followup patch for Iec8854749a1df81eb6a7154d3f951e176c69156d
that left some other unused code in tree. This patch attempts to remove
the remaining pieces.

Related-Bug: 2002839
Change-Id: Ie297dfba17deb79b38cf9f6eccf4f1a8e9e5060a
Signed-off-by: Jakub Libosvar <libosvar@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Make tests pass after 2038

time.time is used to not just shift the exiry time further into the future.

This bug was found while working on reproducible builds for openSUSE.

Change-Id: I146be9afa3ef54288218daa7ae21f7a7cb5aab67

commit_message:
Remove unicode literal from code

All strings are considered as unicode literal string from Python 3.

This patch drops the explicit unicode literal (u'...')
appearances from the unicode strings.

Change-Id: Ib452429e937dd859d150681740fb77292dbeaebb

commit_message:
Use TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE

UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE is old name and deprecated
This allows to use upper-constraints file as more
readable way instead of UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE=<lower-constraints file>.

Change-Id: I3f14c1092259b6f019a9718a3b40212c4412e9fd

commit_message:
Remove translation sections from setup.cfg

These translation sections are not needed anymore, Babel can
generate translation files without them.

heat stack-show <stack_name> failed if <stack_name> is chinese.
fix it before requesting to cover all url cases.

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-02-17 03:41:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient/commit/37957a33f850f2b48c1becc78c23b08ed4b568a5', 'message': "Add include credentials support in SessionClient

doesn't include credentials or include_pass key. Hence even if the user
passes '--include_pass' in heat call for eg.

the credentials were not being pass in request headers. A workaround
for this was to manually pass --os-auth-token and --os-no-client-auth

supports include_pass

commit_message:
Add include credentials support in SessionClient

http._construct_http_client returns two kinds of clients, HTTPClient if
session not provided and SessionClient if session is provided. By
default heat creates a session from user credentials so SessionClient
is returned by this method most of the time. However the SessionClient
doesn't include credentials or include_pass key. Hence even if the user
passes '--include_pass' in heat call for eg.
`heat --include_pass stack-create -f template.yaml stack1`
the credentials were not being pass in request headers. A workaround
for this was to manually pass --os-auth-token and --os-no-client-auth
which forces creation of HTTPClient by _construct_http_client which
supports include_pass

To resolve this, Update the _construct_http_client to include
credentials params in SessionClient and implement credentials_headers
logic in SessionClient to pass credentials in headers.
SessionClient __init__ is overridden to pop out these credentials
before calling super so we don't break legacy code.

Change-Id: I6bc841b78e6121f2daae89a10061c40b6c5022fb
Closes-Bug: #1665321
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient refs/changes/13/435213/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # With include_pass client.include_pass = True client.username = 'user' client.password = 'pass' self.assertEqual({ 'X-Auth-User':'user', 'X-Auth-Key':'pass' },client.credentials_headers()) # With include_pass and user/pass None client.include_pass = True client.username = None client.password = None self.assertEqual({},client.credentials_headers()) def test_construct_http_client(self): # Include_pass None client = http._construct_http_client(session=mox.IgnoreArg()) self.assertIsInstance(client, http.SessionClient) self.assertEqual(client.username, None) self.assertEqual(client.password, None) self.assertEqual(client.include_pass, False) # Include_pass False client = http._construct_http_client(session=mox.IgnoreArg(), include_pass=False, username='user', password='pass') self.assertIsInstance(client, http.SessionClient) self.assertEqual(client.username, 'user') self.assertEqual(client.password, 'pass') self.assertEqual(client.include_pass, False) # Include_pass True client = http._construct_http_client(session=mox.IgnoreArg(), include_pass=True, username='user', password='pass') self.assertIsInstance(client, http.SessionClient) self.assertEqual(client.username, 'user') self.assertEqual(client.password, 'pass') self.assertEqual(client.include_pass, True)

commit_message:
delete bash_completion in subcommand

There are two "completion" in the subcommand table: bash-completion
and bash_completion. but "bash_completion" is useless, so delete
it and extra code.

Change-Id: I7e6d44c1393e9d719890ae79ffd757ff0022391e
Closes-Bug: #1670123

commit_message:
Handle 408 and 503 error by trying once more.

If 408(timeout), 503(service unavailable) errors
encountered then handle the error by requesting
one more time.

Change-Id: I6b014265d149c01c7df9cbe7c9fc112739726add
Closes-Bug: #1535750

Add extra functional tests in heatclient

For now, there are several heat osc CLIs which do not have own
functional tests in heatclient/tests/functional/osc/v1.
I think it is time to add some for heatclient.

Add functional test for 'openstack stack list'
                        'openstack stack snapshot list'

commit_message:
Specific error for heat template passed as env template

If user specifies heat template in place of environment template
then provide an meaningful error message reflecting the mistake
Adding testcase for the same.

Closes-Bug: #1524257
Change-Id: Ic5121fa82f9487233ad8da37899ce4b3638b4f89
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient refs/changes/89/263889/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: HEAT_SECTIONS = ('heat_template_version', 'description', 'outputs', 'resources') if param in HEAT_SECTION: raise ValueError('heat template has been passed instead of enviroment template') else: raise ValueError(_('environment has wrong section "%s"') % param)
deleted_lines: raise ValueError(_('environment has wrong section "%s"') % param)

commit_message:
Use devstack functions to manage swift/keystone services

... instead of implementing our own logics. Also, the fstab entry is
already managed by the core devstack.

Change-Id: I6a8fbcfebf1e501f41ac82117688572533ae624d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/storlets refs/changes/17/904917/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: source $DEVSTACK_DIR/lib/keystone start_keystone start_swift stop_keystone stop_swift sudo sh -c "echo \"${SWIFT_DISK_IMAGE} ${SWIFT_DATA_DIR}/drives/sdb1 xfs loop\" >> /etc/fstab"
deleted_lines: swift-init --run-dir ${SWIFT_DATA_DIR}/run/ all start /usr/local/bin/uwsgi /etc/keystone/keystone-uwsgi-public.ini &> /dev/null & /usr/local/bin/uwsgi /etc/keystone/keystone-uwsgi-admin.ini &> /dev/null & sh -c 'ps aux | pgrep uwsgi | xargs kill -9' stop_swift sudo sh -c 'echo "/opt/stack/data/swift/drives/images/swift.img /opt/stack/data/swift/drives/sdb1 xfs loop" >> /etc/fstab'

Make the tests tree more clear

We'd better keep the main files in heatclient consistent with its tests.

openstack orchestration resource type show list output in json that is

Change-Id: I5306aae65e6127190ffa5f0ef60879f90becef7c
Closes-Bug: #1643550

commit_message:
Fix openstack orchestration resource type show output format.

openstack orchestration resource type show list output in json that is
not in the default table format as most of the other commands list.
changed the defaultformat from YamlFormat to RawFormat

Change-Id: I5306aae65e6127190ffa5f0ef60879f90becef7c
Closes-Bug: #1643550
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient refs/changes/10/411710/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class ResourceTypeShow(format_utils.RawFormat):

commit_message:
Add HTTP Basic/Digest auth

This commit adds support to HTTP Basic/Digest auth when fetching
HTTP content.

commit_message:
Pin pyparsing to 3.0.9

Pyparsing was bumped up to 3.1.1 in ab0dcbdda28753cca86e162b9ae2fcb1aa99d001 however, Gnocchi has it pinned to "<3.1.0"[1] because of issue[2].

3.1.2 is expected to contain the fix for this issue. Once Gnocchi uses it, revert this change.

[1] https://github.com/gnocchixyz/gnocchi/blob/master/setup.cfg#L52-L54
[2] https://github.com/pyparsing/pyparsing/issues/504

Change-Id: I6a6a3bd42deda2d74b7a53d225c6f0c5406c4b8b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/54/897654/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Remove tap-as-a-service-tempest-plugin

tap-as-a-service-tempest-plugin tests were moved to
neutron-tempest-plugin when tap-as-a-service was
revived from x/, so this tempest plugin can be
removed from generate-tempest-plugins-list.py

Change-Id: I0a796b9bd5206092d5aee583db89c4227c626ff8

commit_message:
Verify that instance can boot after volume retype with migration

This tests that an instance can still boot after a volume retype with
migration across backends.

Note: The TestVolumeMigrateRetypeAttached tests only run if there are
multiple backends configured in CINDER_ENABLED_BACKENDS.

Related-Bug: #2019190

Change-Id: Ia88375dd08e0ba2c897fb37c312ef69dab3d001e

good to have basic test coverage either way to make it easier
to understand the implementation.

You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo_config import fixture as cfg_fixture import oslotest.base import designate.conf from designate import context from designate.network_api import fake from designate.network_api import get_network_api CONF = designate.conf.CONF class FakeNetworkAPITest(oslotest.base.BaseTestCase): def setUp(self): super().setUp() self.useFixture(cfg_fixture.Config(CONF)) self.api = get_network_api('fake') self.context = context.DesignateContext( user_id='12345', project_id='54321', ) self.addCleanup(fake.reset_floatingips) def test_list_floatingips(self): fake.allocate_floatingip(self.context.project_id) fake.allocate_floatingip('12345') self.assertEqual(1, len(self.api.list_floatingips(self.context))) def test_list_floatingips_is_admin(self): fake.allocate_floatingip(self.context.project_id) fake.allocate_floatingip('12345') self.context.is_admin = True self.assertEqual(2, len(self.api.list_floatingips(self.context))) def test_allocate_floatingip(self): fip = fake.allocate_floatingip(self.context.project_id) self.assertIn('192.0.2', fip['address']) self.assertEqual('RegionOne', fip['region']) self.assertIn('id', fip) def test_deallocate_floatingip(self): fip = fake.allocate_floatingip(self.context.project_id) self.assertIn('192.0.2', fip['address']) self.assertEqual('RegionOne', fip['region']) self.assertIn('id', fip) self.assertIsNone(fake.deallocate_floatingip(self.context.project_id))

req_mock.get( self.api_address, status_code=404, ) self.backend._check_zone_exists = mock.Mock() self.backend._check_zone_exists.side_effect = [False, True] self.backend.delete_zone = mock.Mock() self.backend.delete_zone.side_effect = exceptions.Backend() self.assertRaisesRegex( exceptions.Backend, '500 Server Error', self.backend.create_zone, self.context, self.zone ) @requests_mock.mock() def test_get_master(self): target_master = objects.PoolTargetMaster(host='192.0.2.1', port=53) self.backend.options = objects.PoolTargetMasterList( objects=[target_master] ) self.assertEqual(target_master, self.backend._get_master()) def test_get_master_no_master(self): backend = impl_ns1.NS1Backend( objects.PoolTarget.from_dict({ 'id': '4588652b-50e7-46b9-b688-a9bad40a873e', 'type': 'ns1', 'masters': [], 'options': [ {'key': 'api_endpoint', 'value': '192.0.2.3'}, {'key': 'api_token', 'value': 'test_key'}, ], }) ) self.assertRaisesRegex( exceptions.Backend, 'list index out of range', backend._get_master ) @requests_mock.mock() def test_check_zone_exists_server_error(self, req_mock): req_mock.get( self.backend._check_zone_exists, self.zone )

added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from unittest import mock import oslotest.base from designate.api.v2.controllers.zones.tasks import abandon from designate.central import rpcapi from designate import objects class TestAbandonAPI(oslotest.base.BaseTestCase): def setUp(self): super().setUp() self.central_api = mock.Mock() self.zone = objects.Zone( id='1e8952a5-e5a4-426a-afab-4cd10131a351', name='example.com.', email='example@example.com' ) mock.patch.object(rpcapi.CentralAPI, 'get_instance', return_value=self.central_api).start() self.controller = abandon.AbandonController() @mock.patch('pecan.response') @mock.patch('pecan.request') def test_post_all_move_error(self, mock_request, mock_response): mock_request.environ = {'context': mock.Mock()} mock_delete_zone = mock.Mock() mock_delete_zone.deleted_at = None self.central_api.delete_zone.return_value = mock_delete_zone self.controller.post_all(self.zone.id) self.assertEqual(500, mock_response.status_int)

commit_message:
add suse_py311 flavor to explicitly render templates for py311

This is needed when py 3.11 is not the primary python version
(e.g. SLE15).

Change-Id: I362ec318a0c63f54469eb3267b5b8d868856bbdf

commit_message:
Replace find_module function

find_module function was deprecated in Python 3.4 [1] and later removed
in Python 3.12 [2], the find_spec function should be used instead. This
change is necessary for proper Python 3.12 support.

[1] https://docs.python.org/3.4/library/importlib.html#importlib.abc.MetaPathFinder.find_module
[2] https://github.com/python/cpython/issues/98040

Change-Id: I8354918d6548192dea3492eb2ee682d323559912
Signed-off-by: Petr Vank <arkamar@atlas.cz>

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-01-11 17:58:35.000000000', 'files': ['placement/wsgi.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/placement/commit/3567bed6931ce9b80375fcd097d4ef9d065dd9c2', 'message': "support multiple config files with apache

commit_message:
support multiple config files with apache

Unlike uwsgi, apache mod_wsgi does not support passing
commandline arguments to the python wsgi script it invokes.

As a result while you can pass --config-file when hosting the
api and metadata wsgi applications with uwsgi there is no
way to use multiple config files with mod_wsgi.

This change mirrors how this is supported in keystone and
nova today by intoducing a new OS_PLACEMENT_CONFIG_FILES
env var to allow operators to optional pass a ';' delimited
list of config files to load.

Closes-Bug: #1994056
Change-Id: I17ab6b512734949d5c4eae7f5120ffa26c22f91e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/placement refs/changes/63/869863/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Set the correct firewall group status when the router is updated

By default, it will set firewall group status to ACTIVE when router is
updated, even if then firewall group is not associate with any policies.
This patch set firewall group status to ACTIVE when it has associate
with policies.

Related-Bug: #2047325
Change-Id: I86e5f2becda788fdf1d1d546aa0cb22a124e6a20

This patch fixes an issue where if the user attempts to use a
certificate that does not have a subject or CN, we would fail to create
a listener using the certificate.
Per the x.509 specification, a blank subject is allowed as long as the
subjectAltName extension is present in the certificate.

commit_message:
Fix issue with certificates with no subject or CN

This patch fixes an issue where if the user attempts to use a
certificate that does not have a subject or CN, we would fail to create
a listener using the certificate.
Per the x.509 specification, a blank subject is allowed as long as the
subjectAltName extension is present in the certificate.
Octavia will now check for the a valid subAltName if the subject CN can
not be retrieved. If both are missing an appropriate error is raised for
the user.

Closes-Bug: #2043582
Change-Id: I06911f42b9bf29cf9a5f2e76d8333d8a2f1bc60b

Fix Share Networks dashboard

Patch adds some awareness of optional parameters at Share Networks
dashboard rendering. Currently, some of them are treated as required,
leading to page render fail
